title: Understanding the Problem
text: We need to calculate the pH of a weak acid solution. The given concentration of the acid is $$0.0500$$ M, and the acid dissociation constant (Ka) is $$3.5e-5$$. We will use the approximation that the dissociation is small compared to the initial concentration.

title: Setting Up the Equation
text: For a weak acid HA, the dissociation in water can be represented as: HA ⇌ H⁺ + A⁻. The expression for the acid dissociation constant (Ka) is: Ka $$=$$ (H⁺)(A⁻)/(HA).

title: Using the Approximation
text: Since the dissociation is small, we can assume that the concentration of HA remains approximately $$0.0500$$ M. Therefore, the equation simplifies to: Ka $$=$$ $$\frac{x x}{0.05-x}$$ ≈ $$\frac{x x}{0.05}$$.

title: Solving for $$x$$
text: Solve the equation Ka $$=$$ x²/0.0500 for $$x$$, where Ka $$=$$ $$3.5e-5$$.

title: Calculating pH
text: Once you have the value of $$x$$, which represents the concentration of H⁺ ions, calculate the pH using the formula: pH $$=$$ $$-\ln\left(x\right)$$.

title: Final Calculation
text: Calculate the pH using the value of $$x$$ obtained from the previous step.
